content: Thunderbird retains the last saved password at settings>privacy&security. If that is not the current password, you will need to contact your email provider.
creator: davidsk

content:
1. to ensure you have all the messages, click file>offline>download
  2. install importexporttools NG addon
  3. highlight the desired message folders to save
  4. rightclick and select importexport option to export mbox
  5. repeat for al such folders
  6. now, highlight Local Folders
  7. rightclick and select importexport option to import mbox and select one of the exported folders. repeat for the others.
  8. you now have the messages in Local Folders. If you want them online, you can righclick and select COPY TO a desired online folder. (IMAP was not desired for large-scale uploads. If your folder is huge, you may do better by copying in bunches.)
creator: davidsk

content: Yes, local folders are on your hard drive and not tied to accounts . If your account with them is IMAP, you can copy desired content to local folders to preserve them.
creator: davidsk

content:
Yes, you click Send just like a normal email

When your recipients receive the message, they will see the same information and clicking the link in the message will take them to a page where they can download the attachment. The message looks like:

"I've attached a file to this message using Thunderbird Filelink: [Name of your file] (15.5 MB) [Link to download the file]"

More info Filelink for Large Attachments

creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Use this tool to import mbox files after you unzip the files. https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/?src=ss

Thunderbird does not know how to import a random zip file, which is what you have there, it knows about zip files it creates in it's export guise only. I would suggest you unzip everything you got from google and then import. Note it looks to me like your instructions have essentially exported the all mail folder. None of he individual labels will be included in that file is my guess. So each email address will import a a folder with the email address in the name and everything in the account under that one folder. Google by default do not create a separate zip for each label, so you might find your takeout to be in rather indigestible chunks.
creator: MattAuSupport

creator: mozilla98

content:
You would need to copye abook.sqlite and history.sqlite from the backup profile folder to the new profile. To find the current folder, try

- TB menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information

- click 'Profiles' near the bottom > about:profiles > Local Directory > click 'Open Folder' button

That should give you an idea where the backup folder is.
creator: siffemoz

content:
You wait for those making the decisions to work out what they are going to do to recover from this fix for something that was not really broken. Personally my feeling is leave it as it was. But that is not the way these guys think.

See https://thunderbird.topicbox.com/groups/planning/T42889d86e87f0dcf/naming-things-is-hard-especially-folders and these related bugs, which are also mentioned in the first link. Bug 2001557 - folders are renamed in TB 146.0b3+ - imap (and ews) folders do not use the same name as used on server. Bug 1993842 - special folders (spam, trash, ...) renamed to english Bug 1998456 - Folder names do not match names on server and personally created folders renamed by Thunderbird.
